Topic.Title: UNIONIZED FAST FOOD WORKERS STRIKE DEMAND WAGES BE DOUBLED IMMEDIATELY

Message.Msg: I worked at McDonalds part time as a high school student. As a kid I knew that McDonalds was not going to substantially improve my standard of living unless I became a franchise owner. There are lots of jobs that pay alot better than a McDonalds manager. So anyone of the minimum wage workers whose only ambition is to take orders or flip burgers and to be as lazy as possible for a lifetime and expect McDonalds to pay them the same salary as a surgeon or engineer is a moron and a fool. Of course I got trade school training in plumbing which paid alot better than McDonalds burger flipping with the intent of eventually owning my own plumbing company. Now I own my own plumbing business and I live very comfortable. To achieve a nice standard of living requires desire, drive, goals and alot of effort and work. It is not for lazy bums who have no skills, no drive, no desire, and expect everything handed to them for choosing to be a loser.

Message.Title: Unveiling Huge Breakthrough Technology Next Week
Message.Msg: Concurrent (CCUR) could become biggest play of next week, started breaking out yesterday! On Monday, CCUR will unveil breakthrough technology that will allow cable TV companies to monetize the 6.8 billion annual free on demand video streams being watched worldwide. CCUR will allow them to insert targeted personalized video ads into free on demand videos "on the fly" while they are being streamed! CCUR is trading at very low valuation and could become a takeover target with #1 market share in video on demand (VOD) technology space! Time Warner Cable is now using the 6th generation of CCUR's technology. CCUR won Emmy Award for their "start over" technology that they deployed in the U.S. for Time Warner Cable (TWC) and Bright House. Soon, CCUR will launch their patented cloud based network DVR technology that will eliminate the need for physical DVR devices and make them obsolete like VCRs. CCUR's business is about to boom as cable TV companies get ready to invest heavily to upgrade their infrastructure to support multi-screen video delivery. Virgin Media (VMED) the largest cable TV company in the UK with an enterprise value of $23 billion just announced that they are currently deploying CCUR's MediaHawk technology to support a new service called Virgin TV Anywhere, which will allow VMED's 3.8mm subscribers to watch on demand content from any location using their tablet, smartphone, or other IP connected device! CCUR's EPS is rapidly growing on a quarter-to-quarter basis and last quarter was up 100% from previous quarter and 300% from two quarters ago.

Message.Title: Look this works for me but you tea billies are getting screwed, LOL
Message.Msg: thanks for being stupid suckers, when corporations pay low taxes I as a large shareholder benefit. In recent decades, corporate tax revenue has plunged, falling from about 6 percent of gross domestic product in the 1950′s to less than 2 percent today, due to a proliferation of corporate tax breaks and the use of offshore tax havens. According to the Congressional Budget Office, in fact, corporate tax receipts as a share of corporate profits have hit their lowest point in 40 years: Corporate tax receipts as a share of profits are at their lowest level in at least 40 years. Total corporate federal taxes paid fell to 12.1% of profits earned from activities within the U.S. in fiscal 2011, which ended Sept. 30, according to the Congressional Budget Office. That’s the lowest level since at least 1972. And well below the 25.6% companies paid on average from 1987 to 2008.Tax avoidance from corporations and wealthy individuals has a cost for individual taxpayers and small businesses, according to a new report from the U.S. Public Interest Research Group. According to U.S. PIRG, tax dodging cost individual taxpayers $1,026 and each small business $3,067 in 2012.

Message.Title: tea billies working to make sure kids are stupid enough to vote GOP
Message.Msg: Following is a statement by U.S. Secretary of Education Arne Duncan on a legislative proposal in South Carolina to block implementation of the Common Core academic standards: “The idea that the Common Core standards are nationally-imposed is a conspiracy theory in search of a conspiracy. The Common Core academic standards were both developed and adopted by the states, and they have widespread bipartisan support. GOP leaders like Jeb Bush and governors Mitch Daniels, Chris Christie, and Bill Haslam have supported the Common Core standards because they realize states must stop dummying down academic standards and lying about the performance of children and schools. In fact, South Carolina lowered the bar for proficiency in English and mathematics faster than any state in the country from 2005 to 2009, according to research by the National Center for Education Statistics. “That’s not good for children, parents, or teachers. I hope South Carolina lawmakers will heed the voices of teachers who supported South Carolina’s decision to stop lowering academic standards and set a higher bar for success. And I hope lawmakers will continue to support the state’s decision to raise standards, with the goal of making every child college- and career-ready in today’s knowledge economy.”

Message.Title: More results from the communist party.
Message.Msg: The government-backed electric car company Fisker Automotive laid off about 160 workers Friday, or roughly 75 percent of the automaker's staff, as it has struggled to find financial backing that would allow it to continue building its high concept clean cars. The layoff announcement came as the innovative start up faces a looming repayment on a loan from the U.S. Department of Energy, and as reports have swirled that it could be preparing to file for bankruptcy. As with the failed solar firm Solyndra, the green car company was once an early pick by the Obama Administration to be part of America's clean energy future. The Obama Energy Department had approved Fisker for a government loan up to $529 million.
